DataElement.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Derived American Joint Committee on Cancer Integer::7 Edition Post Therapeutic Procedure Metastasis Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: This field contains the numeric representation for the post-treatment AJCC 7th edition M and is derived from CS coded fields using the CS algorithm.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The AJCC "M" component that is derived from CS coded fields, using the CS algorithm, effective with 2004 diagnosis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Property.preferredDefinition: To take, obtain, or receive from a source; having been determined by mathematical computation. :Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer.

Concepts.definition: The source from which something comes or issues; to take, obtain, or receive from a source.

The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Derived American Joint Committee on Cancer Integer::7 Edition Post Therapeutic Procedure Metastasis Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: To take, obtain, or receive from a source; having been determined by mathematical computation._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._A number with no fractional part.::7_The form in which a text (especially a printed book) is published._Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order._An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process._Refers to cancer that has spread from the original (primary) tumor to distant organs or distant lymph nodes._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Derived American Joint Committee on Cancer Integer::7 Edition Post Therapeutic Procedure Distant Metastasis Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: To take, obtain, or receive from a source; having been determined by mathematical computation. :A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:A number with no fractional part.::7:The form in which a text (especially a printed book) is published.:Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.:Refers to cancer that has spread from the original (primary) tumor to distant organs or distant lymph nodes.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: The source from which something comes or issues; to take, obtain, or receive from a source.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The form in which a text (especially a printed book) is published.
Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

A biological process that involves the transfer and growth of cancer cells from the site of the primary tumor. Relocation of malignant cells during metastasis can be restricted to movement within a specific tissue/organ or may entail migration to a distal locus within the body. This phenotype is a characteristic of all malignant tumors.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ValueDomain.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ReferenceDocuments.name: AJCC Coding Information
ReferenceDocuments.description: See the most current version of the Collaborative Stage Data Collection System (http://cancerstaging.org/cstage/manuals.html), for rules and site-specific codes and coding structures.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Derived Post-treatment-7 M
ReferenceDocuments.description: This data item belongs to the Collaborative Stage (CS) Data Collection System which is based on the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 6th and 7th editions. AJCC T, N, M plus descriptors and AJCC staging components are composed of combinations of characters, numbers, and/or special characters and can be of varying lengths. To more easily handle these components a numeric code was assigned to each unique category for each T, N, M plus descriptors and AJCC stage for 6th and 7th editions. This field contains the numeric representation for the post-treatment AJCC 7th edition 'M' and is derived from CS coded fields using the CS algorithm. This numeric representation is referred to as the 'storage' code and its associated label is referred to as the 'display' code. Explanations of the 'storage' codes and their corresponding 'display' codes can be found in the most current version of the Collaborative Stage Data Collection System (http://cancerstaging.org/cstage/manuals.html). The display code should be used for display on the screen and in reports. Effective for cases diagnosed 2012+.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NAACCR 16, Data Stds/Dict.
